reviewText: I, my wife and my daughter saw this filmed performance of the Phantom in a local movie theatre and we all loved it!  Theatre purists may argue that there is nothing as good as live theatre but I can't agree.  I saw Phantom on stage in Toronto years ago and had excelent seats, yet I was more captivated by this filmed version.  The advantage of the Royal Albert version is that it had roving camera eyes -- when a long shot was required, as with the chandelier scene, the camera was viewing from an audience seat; when a close-up of the actors' faces was required, the camera was right there.  (How they do this without intruding on the performance or stepping on the actors' toes, I can't imagine.)  The advantage is far better and more intimate viewer involvement in the performance.  Of course, another advantage is that this video is a lot cheaper than the price of a theatre seat at a major venue.  This is a wonderful performance with top-notch performers and is filmed beautifully.  My only complaint, and it's a fixable one, is that at the end of the play, Andrew Llyold Webber comes out, speaks a bit, introduces Michael Crawford and Sarah Brightman (the original cast members) and four other former Phantoms who then sing with Ms Brightman.  It's a pleasant bit of business but anti-climatic to the play: it takes away from the emotional power of the main show.  I don't know how the DVD is formatted --whether this self-congratulatory part at the end is separated from the main film -- but my suggestion is that when Sir Andrew shows up, hit the stop button.  Watch this latter bit at a later time.  Enjoy this performance, as I think anyone who loves Phatom will.
summary: Wonderful!  Better than a Live Performance!

reviewText: While this is an enjoyable performance of Phantom, it is also a little bit odd.  I can't for the life of me understand why they chose to stage this, a show that needs fly space, a proscenium, and wings, in a hall that has none of those things.  This production, in which the theatre itself is practically a character in the show, is a bit of a fish out of water for that reason.  The solution was to use large, low-res video screens in place of much of the scenery.  When seen in person, these probably looked pretty good, but when shot up close, as in this presentation, they look terribly pixelated and they distract from some good performances.Speaking of which, Sierra Boggess is a great Christine.  Her voice is much less shrill than Sarah Brightman's and her performance is top notch.  Ramin Karimloo, on the other hand, gives it the old college try, but he's miscast.  He's too slight of build and his voice is a bit too perfect.  Maybe I'm just biased.  I saw Michael Crawford perform the role on Broadway and don't think anyone else has nailed it since.  Crawford, who appears here briefly during extended curtain calls and encores, had a haunting quality and a physical presence that Karimloo simply lacks.Still, despite the issues, this is a good production and the music sounds as good as ever.  You owe it to yourself to see this if you've ever been a fan of Phantom, if for no other reason than to see the bits with ALW, Brightman, and Crawford at the end.  I only wish Crawford had performed that night.

reviewText: And I'm not just saying that because out of the Phantom makeup Ramin Karimloo is gorgeous. ;-) Sierra Boggess, his Christine, has the most expressive eyes and face I've seen in forever. When she smiles, she smiles with her eyes, and when they sing "Point of No Return", she looks as if he's already seduced her.A friend first sent me the link on YouTube to the finale. Seeing all six Phantoms on stage together was a thrill. (I don't think Michael Crawford sang, but he did wave very enthusiastically.) So as soon as I learned it was going to be aired on PBS, I made sure to set up the VCR to tape it.It was good, even with all the pledge breaks, and I put it on my Amazon wish list. (The price on Amazon is excellent, although I don't understand why the CD is actually more expensive.) I ordered it, and it arrived last week.Now, you have to understand this about me: I'll order a DVD and it can sit in its wrapper for weeks, months, years before I finally watch it. That wasn't the case with Phantom. I've already watched it three times, and I'll probably watch it again tonight.The only quibble I have is with the sound. At times I could see Ramin's lips moving, but I couldn't hear anything. And when he says to Christine, "You... try... my... patience...." you have to be listening really hard to hear it. But seriously? That's a very minor quibble.He's made this Phantom very sympathetic. His cry, "Why, Christine? Why?" broke my heart. I wanted Christine to choose him. Yes, I know he killed, apparently without compunction, but some people are alive only because it's against the law to kill them. *cough*This is the actual play, not a concert, and while the chandelier doesn't actually come down, it does seem to explode.The music, the sets, the costumes, the acting... it all adds up to a magnificent experience.Oh, and right now? The price on Amazon has been reduced. So don't sit there reading this! Go and buy it! I promise you, you won't regret it!

reviewText: The DVD will contained the live streaming held on October 2, 2011 at the Royal Albert Hall.  I had the privilege of seeing it in the theater in the U.S. on 10/2/11 and once again on 10/5/11 as a rebroadcasted Encore performance.  I'm so excited that I'll be able to watch it again and again.  The taping of the show and cinematography were spectacular.  You by no means feel like you are in a seat in the audience watching it from may rows in front of the stage.  No, you are up close, on stage, beholding closeups of the various performers play their iconic roles to perfection.  You see the costumes like you've never seen them before, the rage and hurt in the Phantom's eyes, the conflict and yearning of Christine for two men.  The performances of Ramin Karimloo (Phantom), Sierra Boggess (Christine), and Hadley Fraser (Raoul) are nothing less than brilliant, as well as the rest of the cast.  If you love Phantom on stage, you'll love this DVD. The after performance reprisals of the Phantom of the Opera and the Music of the Night with legends such as Sarah Brightman, Anthony Warlow, John Owen Jones, and Colm Wilkinson will move you to tears, plus the appearance of Michael Crawford, Andrew Lloyd Webber (of course), Cameron Mackintosh, and Charles Hart.  This DVD is a Phantom keepsake indeed.

reviewText: I have attended a live Broadway-touring company production of Phantom, own and view frequently Andrew Lloyd Webber's Phantom movie starring Gerard Butler and was curious to see the 25th anniversary London production at the historic Prince Albert Hall when PBS showed this production once again as part of their annual fundraiser.  It is magnificent:  the voice of the actress who plays Christine is pure and absolutely outstanding; several of the other cast members' voices are also excellent although I preferred a couple of the actors' voices from the movie to a few of this production.  My PBS station used this DVD as a premium along with the 2-CD sound track for a contribution of $185.00.  This DVD was less than $20 from amazon.com and includes the anniversary celebration of the original cast members from the first London production which was a treat seldom seen by audiences, including Sarah Brightman and four of the previous Phantoms singing hits from the show and some of the people who developed Phantom for the stage production 2 1/2 decades earlier.  Andrew Lloyd Webber hosted the celebration at the conclusion of the play and you could see the emotion in his face as he listened to and reacted to the audience's joy.  This DVD is a bargain for anyone who loves musical theatre at its finest and has not seen the longest-running musical ever to play on Broadway in the U.S.---and it certainly costs less than a trip to London.  Some  reviewers have stated that they prefer seeing the production live and a couple did not like the Phantom movie of 2004 but I love each of the three:  live, 2004 movie and this 25th anniversary production of 2012.  This would make a great addition to a DVD library for theatre and/or Phantom fans and/or gifts along with the 2-CD sound track from this 25th anniversary London production.  It is magnificent and is a keeper.

reviewText: This would be a perfect Blu-Ray if it was not the sound inconsistencies. I give 5 stars just for the Show including the wonderful music, and spectacular performance of the entire cast, 4.5 stars for the stunning picture, but only 4 stars for the sound, because it lacked dynamic and volume for the vocals that often got a very low level sound compared to the sound of the orchestra. A wonderful Show that was almost damaged by a mistaken sound engineering. Also, lacked best sound involvement, and even the stereo effect was poorly exploited by putting the whole orchestra at center stage, unless I choose to play stereo sound with Dolby PLIIx when, in this case, the sound is more dynamic and engaging. However, when I saw the "grand finale", all the criticisms that I made with respect to the sound does not seem so important. From this point the sound gets more dynamic and with more volume, and ends up enriching greatly the guest Sarah Brightman's participation in the presence of the current and old phantoms, and together they conclude the show with an  "grand, and exciting, finale". I just read a review from a Brazilian who complains about the errors from the lyrics of songs in Portuguese-BR subtitles. Yes, it is true, if someone tries to follow the direction of history with subtitles, the person will be confused and don't  will understand the correct meaning of the phrase.
